skills.name: Calculate the volume of a prism by counting cubes

explanations.A: 9cm³ would be the volume of one layer, because one layer uses 9 cubes. This shape is two layers tall, so what will the volume be?
explanations.B: 9cm³ is the volume of one layer, because one layer uses 9 cubes. This shape is two layers tall, so 2x9 = 18cm³.
explanations.C: I think you've counted the number of faces you can see on the shape, so a part of the surface area. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the top layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.
explanations.D: I think you've counted the number of faces you can see on the shape and doubled for the faces you can't see, this would give the surface area. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the top layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.

explanations.A: I think you've counted the number of faces you can see on the shape, so a part of the surface area. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the top layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.
explanations.B: I think you've counted the number of faces you can see on the shape and doubled for the faces you can't see, this would give the surface area. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the top layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.
explanations.C: I think you may have miscounted. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the top layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.
explanations.D: 9cm³ is the volume of the top layer, because one layer uses 9 cubes. This shape is six layers tall, so 6x9 = 54cm³.

explanations.A: I think you've counted the number of cubes you can see on the shape, however, there are some cubes you cannot see. To help, find the number of cubes on the front layer, then multiply by how many layers there are.
explanations.B: I think you've counted the number of faces you can see on the shape and doubled for the faces you can't see, this would give the surface area. To find the volume, try to look at how many cubes form the front layer, and then multiply by the number of layers there are.
explanations.C: 6cm³ would be the volume of the front layer, because it is made of 6 cubes. This shape is made of two layers, what will the total volume be?
explanations.D: 6cm³ would be the volume of the front layer, because it is made of 6 cubes. There are two layers on this shape, so the volume is 2x6 = 12cm³.

explanations.A: I think you've missed some of the cubes out. Take care to notice the cubes at the back on the bottom.
explanations.B: If we split this shape into three layers from left to right, it might help us. The shape on the left is an L-shape, consisting of 3 cubes, in the middle we have 1 cube, and on the right we have another L-shape of 3 cubes. Adding those together we have 3+1+3=7cm³
explanations.C: I think you've counted the cubes you can see, but there are some you cannot see, supporting other cubes. Take care to notice the cubes at the back on the bottom.
explanations.D: I think you've counted the faces rather than the total cubes. Remember that sometimes we can see 3 faces of a cube, but we only need to count it once.

explanations.A: The top layer is made up of 9 cubes. As there are 3 layers we have 3 lots of 9 cubes which is 27.
explanations.B: 3 x 3 would find the number of cubes in the top layer, but how many do we have in total? Think about how many layers of 3 x 3 cubes there are
explanations.C: I think you found the surface area of the cube. Think about how many cubes make up the top layer, and how many layers there are in total.
explanations.D: I think you spotted a square number, but this isn't how many cubes there are in the shape. Think about how many cubes make up the top layer, and how many layers there are in total.

explanations.A: I think you found the surface area of the cube. Think about how many cubes make up the top layer, and how many layers there are in total.
explanations.B: I think you tried to count the visible cubes, remember there are some that we can't see. Think about how many cubes make up the top layer, and how many layers there are in total.
explanations.C: The top layer is made up of 8 cubes. As there are 3 layers we have 3 lots of 8 cubes which is 24.
explanations.D: 4 x 3 would find the number of cubes in the front layer, but how many do we have in total? Think about how many layers of 4 x 3 cubes there are?

explanations.A: I think you counted the faces around the outside, but to find the volume we want to know how many cubes there are... How many cubes would you need to build this shape? Try looking at the top face to help you.
explanations.B: So close but check the units - do we measure volume in square units?
explanations.C: It looks like you counted the faces of the cubes you can see, but to find the volume we want to know how many cubes there are. How many 3D cubes would it take to build this shape?
explanations.D: This shape is made out of 6 small cubes, so its volume is 6 cubic units.

explanations.A: It looks like you counted the faces of the cubes you can see, but to find the volume we want to know how many cubes there are. How many 3D cubes would it take to build this shape?
explanations.B: This shape is made out of 5 small cubes, so its volume is 5 cubic units.
explanations.C: So close but check the units - do we measure volume in square units?
explanations.D: I think you counted the faces around the outside, but to find the volume we want to know how many cubes there are... How many cubes would you need to build this shape?

explanations.A: This is tricky - if the base was a 3x3 square layer of cubes, you would be correct, but look at the back view - there are two cubes "missing" at the back.
explanations.B: I think you have only counted the visible cubes, but can you see that not all the cubes are visible in each diagram? How many cubes are in the bottom layer altogether?
explanations.C: Using the two views we can see that the bottom layer has 7 cubes, the middle layer has 2 and the top has 1, making 10 cubic units in total.
explanations.D: I think you have counted the visible cubes in the front layer, but can you see that not all the cubes are visible in each diagram? How many cubes are in the bottom layer altogether?

explanations.A: This is tricky - if the base was a 3x3 square layer of cubes, you would be correct, but look at the back view - there are three cubes "missing" at the back.
explanations.B: Using the two views we can see that the bottom layer has 6 cubes, the middle layer has 2 and the top has 2, making 10 cubic units in total.
explanations.C: I think you have only counted the visible cubes in the back view, but you need to use both views to see how many cubes are in the bottom layer, middle layer and top layer. Add these together to find the volume.
explanations.D: I think you have only counted the visible cubes in the front view, but you need to use both views to see how many cubes are in the bottom layer, middle layer and top layer. Add these together to find the volume.
